questions.text: A 50-year-old female is presenting to the gynecology OPD with abdominal distention and reduced appetite. Her physical examination revealed the presence of moderate ascites, and an ultrasound revealed the presence of an ovarian mass. The ascitic fluid was tapped, revealing elevated CA 125 and the presence of malignant cells. Genetic analysis of the cells showed increased activity of the telomerase enzyme. The enzyme promotes cell growth by which of the following actions?

options.label: D
options.text: Promotion of G1 to S progression

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prevention of chromosome shortening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase prevents chromosome shortening, allowing cancer cells to divide indefinitely, which contributes to their immortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is not properly matched?

options.label: A
options.text: Anaphylaxis on blood transfusion: IgA deficiency

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased B cells and T cells due to adenosine deaminase: SCID

options.label: C
options.text: Defective CD40L and CD40 interaction: class switching defect

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiac defects, absent thymic shadow X ray, hypercalcemia: DiGeorge syndrome

questions.correct_answer: D. Cardiac defects, absent thymic shadow X ray, hypercalcemia: DiGeorge syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardiac defects, absent thymic shadow on X-ray, hypercalcemia: DiGeorge syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DiGeorge syndrome is associated with cardiac defects, absent thymic shadow, and hypocalcemia—not hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented in the OPD with abdominal discomfort and was found to have enlarged lymph nodes. Multiple investigations revealed the diagnosis of lymphoma. Combination chemotherapy was prescribed, and after 3 to 4 cycles, there was a significant reduction in the size of the affected nodes. The biopsy of the nodes revealed the presence of shrunken eosinophilic cells within the tumor. Which of the following substances released from the mitochondria has triggered the change observed in the biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytochrome c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytochrome c released from the mitochondria is a key trigger in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis, leading to the activation of caspases and programmed cell death.

questions.text: Enamel-like superstructure is seen in which of the following CNS lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Craniopharyngioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma is characterized by a combination of solid and cystic components, with calcifications that appear enamel-like or tooth-like, often seen in children and young adults.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the graph depicted by the red line? Sickle cell anemia Autoimmune hemolytic anemia Hereditary spherocytosis Thalassemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased osmotic fragility, represented by the red line, is characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, where the RBC membranes are more prone to lysis in hypotonic solutions.

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes?
questions.correct_answer: A. Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of blood sample collection is Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey , ensuring proper sample integrity and avoiding contamination by additives from different tubes.
  • ➤ Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately pertain to amyloidosis? It is an extracellular protein. Apple green birefringence is seen with Congo red under polarized microscopy. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography. AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amyloidosis involves extracellular deposition of beta-pleated sheet proteins that show apple-green birefringence with Congo red staining under polarized light. AL amyloidosis is a primary, not secondary, form of amyloidosis.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their genetic abnormalities:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the paraneoplastic syndromes with associated neoplasm:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman consults a doctor due to persistent malaise for five years and presents with high blood pressure. She passes away unexpectedly within a week. The autopsy reveals her kidneys' external and bisected appearance, as shown in the images. What is the most likely cause of her death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ruptured berry aneurysm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is associated with complications such as berry aneurysms , which can rupture and cause sudden death. This is a frequent cause of mortality in patients with ADPKD, making the rupture of a berry aneurysm the most likely cause of death in this patient.
  • ➤ Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • ➤ berry aneurysms

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with fever, hypotension, diffuse erythematous rash, and confusion. She reports recent use of tampons during menstruation. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Blood and urine cultures are obtained, and she is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravenous fluids. Which of the following is true about the antigen involved here?

options.label: A
options.text: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to the CD4 + molecule causing T cell activation

options.label: D
options.text: Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4 + lymphocytes

questions.correct_answer: B. Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superantigens , such as those causing Toxic Shock Syndrome , bypass the normal antigen presentation process by binding directly to the beta chain of TCR and the MHC class II molecules , leading to excessive T cell activation and a cytokine storm.
  • ➤ Superantigens
  • ➤ Toxic Shock Syndrome
  • ➤ beta chain of TCR
  • ➤ MHC class II molecules

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with a suspected diagnosis of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Renal and CNS involvement is uncommon

options.label: C
options.text: Anti histone antibody levels are low

options.label: D
options.text: The disease remits after withdrawal of the offending drug

questions.correct_answer: C. Anti histone antibody levels are low
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-histone antibody levels are low

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-histone antibodies are typically high in drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE) , and stopping the offending drug usually leads to remission of symptoms.
  • ➤ Anti-histone antibodies are typically high in drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6-month history of fatigue, joint pain, and facial rash exacerbated by sun exposure. She also reports intermittent oral ulcers and hair loss. On physical examination, she has a malar rash over her cheeks and nasal bridge. Laboratory studies reveal anemia, leukopenia, lymphopenia, and elevated anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA). Which technique is most commonly used to identify autoantibodies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Indirect immunofluorescence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indirect immunofluorescence is the preferred and most commonly used technique for detecting anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) , which are often present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • ➤ Indirect immunofluorescence
  • ➤ anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA)

questions.text: Hepatitis B is associated with increased risk of liver cancer in patients because of:

options.label: A
options.text: Increased survival time in host cells

options.label: C
options.text: Enhanced release of tumor suppressor gene products

options.label: D
options.text: Intergration of viral RNA with host DNA

questions.correct_answer: B. High rate of hepatocyte proliferation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High rate of hepatocyte proliferation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B infection leads to liver cancer primarily due to the high rate of hepatocyte proliferation that occurs as part of the liver’s compensatory response to chronic injury and inflammation, increasing the risk of mutations and oncogenesis.
  • ➤ Hepatitis B infection
  • ➤ high rate of hepatocyte proliferation

questions.text: Due to which phenomenon do B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ B cells express both IgM and IgD antibodies on their surface simultaneously due to alternative RNA splicing , a mechanism that allows the same RNA transcript to be spliced in different ways, resulting in the production of both antibody types from the same gene.
  • ➤ IgM and IgD
  • ➤ alternative RNA splicing

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female presents with a bleeding disorder. Upon taking a detailed history, she reveals that her father and sister also have the same bleeding disorder. Which is the most likely disorder in her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Willebrand disease is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with a bleeding disorder affecting both males and females in the family, following an autosomal inheritance pattern .
  • ➤ Von Willebrand disease
  • ➤ autosomal inheritance pattern

questions.text: A 15-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his arms and legs. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of pain in various parts of his body, often triggered by dehydration. On examination, he has tenderness over his extremities, and his spleen is palpable 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin level of 7.5 g/dL, reticulocytosis, and abnormally shaped erythrocytes on a peripheral blood smear. Which of the following is true about such cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

options.label: B
options.text: High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility

options.label: C
options.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility

options.label: D
options.text: High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.correct_answer: D. High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In sickle cell anemia , the abnormal red blood cells exhibit high mechanical fragility but low osmotic fragility , which is characteristic of this disease and its complications, such as hemolytic anemia and vaso-occlusive crises.
  • ➤ sickle cell anemia
  • ➤ high mechanical fragility
  • ➤ low osmotic fragility

questions.text: A 37-year-old male recently diagnosed with membranous glomerulopathy experiences sudden onset flank pain and gross hematuria. On physical examination, there is a left-sided varicocele. Urinalysis reveals increased proteinuria. This patient’s condition is most likely related to urinary loss of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antithrombin III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with membranous glomerulopathy and nephrotic syndrome, the urinary loss of antithrombin III is a key factor in the development of renal vein thrombosis and other thromboembolic complications.
  • ➤ membranous glomerulopathy
  • ➤ urinary loss of antithrombin III
  • ➤ renal vein thrombosis

questions.text: In a known case of breast cancer, Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining for HER2/Neu?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH is recommended when an IHC score of 2+ is observed in breast cancer cases to confirm HER2 gene amplification.
  • ➤ FISH
  • ➤ IHC score of 2+

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast?

options.label: A
options.text: It is presenting as an occult primary

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with familial gastric cancer

options.label: C
options.text: There is over-activity of CDH1 gene

options.label: D
options.text: It tends to be multifocal and bilateral.

questions.correct_answer: C. There is over-activity of CDH1 gene
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) There is over-activity of CDH1 gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In invasive lobular carcinoma , the CDH1 gene is typically underactive , leading to a loss of E-cadherin function. This loss is associated with both lobular carcinoma of the breast and familial diffuse gastric cancer , and the tumor often presents as multifocal and bilateral.
  • ➤ invasive lobular carcinoma
  • ➤ CDH1 gene
  • ➤ underactive
  • ➤ E-cadherin
  • ➤ lobular carcinoma of the breast
  • ➤ familial diffuse gastric cancer

questions.text: Pick the correct statements about hemolytic anemia: Sickle cell anemia has high osmotic fragility and high mechanical fragility Increased HbA2 is seen with iron deficiency anemia Mentzer index helps in the differentiation of thalassemia trait from iron deficiency anemia Donath Landsteiner antibody is seen in cold hemolysin disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mentzer index helps differentiate thalassemia trait from iron deficiency anemia . Donath-Landsteiner antibody is a marker for cold hemolysin disease (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria) .
  • ➤ The Mentzer index helps differentiate thalassemia trait from iron deficiency anemia .
  • ➤ Mentzer index
  • ➤ thalassemia trait
  • ➤ iron deficiency anemia
  • ➤ Donath-Landsteiner antibody is a marker for cold hemolysin disease (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria) .
  • ➤ Donath-Landsteiner antibody
  • ➤ cold hemolysin disease (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with lymphadenopathy and night sweats. A lymph node biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells with inflammatory cells in the background. Flow cytometry of the lymph node specimen is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.correct_answer: B. Clonal expansion of B lymphocytes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clonal expansion of B lymphocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells , which are derived from B cells , making the clonal expansion of B lymphocytes the most likely finding on flow cytometry.
  • ➤ Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • ➤ Reed-Sternberg cells
  • ➤ B cells
  • ➤ clonal expansion of B lymphocytes

questions.text: A research study investigates metabolic changes in cancer cells. Which of the following cellular components is most likely to be upregulated in cancer cells exhibiting the Warburg effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytoplasmic ribosomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Warburg effect leads to increased cytoplasmic ribosomal activity to support the elevated protein synthesis needed for rapid cell proliferation and metabolic shifts in cancer cells.
  • ➤ Warburg effect
  • ➤ cytoplasmic ribosomal activity

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease presents with abdominal discomfort and elevated blood pressure. Imaging reveals multiple clear cell renal cell carcinomas in both kidneys. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the short arm of chromosome 3. What is the most important factor contributing to the development of renal cell carcinoma in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

options.label: D
options.text: Inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene

questions.correct_answer: D. Inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease , the development of renal cell carcinoma is primarily due to the inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene , leading to uncontrolled cell growth, particularly in clear cell RCC.
  • ➤ von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease
  • ➤ renal cell carcinoma
  • ➤ inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with gastrointestinal bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Thromboelastography (TEG) is performed and shows a prolonged reaction time (R-time), decreased angle (α-angle), and reduced maximum amplitude (MA). Which of the following best explains these TEG findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypocoagulability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prolonged R-time , decreased α-angle , and reduced MA seen on TEG, combined with a history of liver cirrhosis and prolonged PT/aPTT, indicate a state of hypocoagulability . Liver cirrhosis impairs the production of clotting factors, fibrinogen, and platelet function, leading to a bleeding tendency.
  • ➤ prolonged R-time
  • ➤ decreased α-angle
  • ➤ reduced MA
  • ➤ hypocoagulability

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with metastatic lung cancer is treated with a targeted therapy directed against an oncogenic mutation specific to their tumor. Despite a poor overall prognosis, the patient experiences a remarkable response to the treatment, with a significant reduction in tumor size. Which of the following concepts best explains this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oncogene addiction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oncogene addiction explains how some tumors, despite their complexity, become highly dependent on a single oncogenic mutation, and targeted therapies directed against this mutation can lead to significant clinical responses, as seen in this patient with metastatic lung cancer.
  • ➤ Oncogene addiction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with redness, swelling, and pain in his left ankle. He reports a recent history of trauma to the ankle. Physical examination reveals erythema, warmth, and swelling localized to the left ankle joint. Laboratory tests show an elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of neutrophils. Which of the following cellular events is the primary characteristic of the acute inflammatory response in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neutrophil recruitment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute inflammation , the primary cellular response is neutrophil recruitment , which is the body's first line of defense to address the injury or infection. Other immune cells, such as macrophages and lymphocytes, are more involved in chronic or later stages of inflammation.
  • ➤ acute inflammation
  • ➤ neutrophil recruitment

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a painless neck mass. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass reveals papillary structures with ground-glass nuclei and nuclear grooves. Immunohistochemical staining shows positive staining for thyroglobulin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is identified by its characteristic papillary structures , ground-glass ("Orphan Annie eye") nuclei , and nuclear grooves , along with positive immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin .
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC)
  • ➤ papillary structures
  • ➤ ground-glass ("Orphan Annie eye") nuclei
  • ➤ nuclear grooves
  • ➤ thyroglobulin

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic is admitted to the hospital with congestive heart failure. Physical examination shows bilateral basal crackles, increased jugular venous pressure, ascites, and peripheral edema. Chest x-ray demonstrates cardiomegaly. Laboratory testing shows mild thrombocytopenia and prolonged prothrombin time (PT). The patient is given intramuscular vitamin K, but his prothrombin time is still prolonged. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s prolonged prothrombin time?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Coagulation factor VII deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's prolonged PT is most likely due to coagulation factor VII deficiency caused by hepatic dysfunction secondary to congestive heart failure . Factor VII is the first factor to become deficient due to its short half-life, leading to the observed coagulation abnormalities.
  • ➤ coagulation factor VII deficiency
  • ➤ hepatic dysfunction
  • ➤ congestive heart failure

questions.text: Animals, especially rodents, subjected to chronic inhalation exposure to formaldehyde develop nasal squamous cell carcinomas. Decreased activity of which of the following genes is likely to be found on cytogenetic studies of the tumor cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) p53

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The development of nasal squamous cell carcinoma following chronic exposure to formaldehyde is most likely associated with decreased activity of the p53 tumor suppressor gene , which plays a key role in preventing the proliferation of damaged cells.
  • ➤ nasal squamous cell carcinoma
  • ➤ decreased activity of the p53 tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by her friends after they found her drowsy and confused. She admits to taking an overdose of acetaminophen about 18 hours ago following a breakup. She is experiencing nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Her liver function tests are markedly elevated, and she is jaundiced. There is no history of liver disease or alcohol abuse. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism of her hepatic injury?
questions.correct_answer: B. Direct hepatotoxicity from free radicals
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Direct hepatotoxicity from free radicals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetaminophen overdose leads to direct hepatotoxicity through the accumulation of toxic metabolites (NAPQI) , which causes free radical formation and subsequent liver cell damage. This is the primary mechanism of liver injury in this case.
  • ➤ direct hepatotoxicity
  • ➤ toxic metabolites (NAPQI)
  • ➤ free radical formation

questions.text: What can be the mechanism by which the phagolysosome causes cell death in autophagy?

options.label: A
options.text: Is both intra and extra cellular

options.label: B
options.text: Can fuse with other organelles directly

options.label: C
options.text: Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

options.label: D
options.text: It is a single membrane structure

questions.correct_answer: C. Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In autophagy , the autophagosome fuses with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome , where cellular materials are degraded. This process is essential for the breakdown and recycling of damaged organelles and can lead to cell death if autophagy is excessive.
  • ➤ autophagy
  • ➤ lysosome
  • ➤ autophagolysosome
  • ➤ cell death

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perineural invasion is not a feature of pleomorphic adenoma , which is a benign tumor. It is commonly seen in malignant tumors , such as adenoid cystic carcinoma .
  • ➤ Perineural invasion
  • ➤ pleomorphic adenoma
  • ➤ benign
  • ➤ malignant tumors
  • ➤ adenoid cystic carcinoma

questions.text: An intracranial mass is removed from a 33-year-old male. The mass is composed of elongated cells that have regular, oval nuclei and demonstrate areas of dense and loose growth patterns. The cells show S-100 immunoreactivity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A schwannoma is characterized by Antoni A and B areas and S-100 immunoreactivity , which distinguish it from other intracranial masses.
  • ➤ schwannoma
  • ➤ Antoni A and B areas
  • ➤ S-100 immunoreactivity

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents in the outpatient department reporting that she passes blood instead of urine during the night. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PIGA gene. She undergoes a series of laboratory tests including the Ham test. What is the primary abnormality detected by the Ham test?

options.label: D
options.text: Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

questions.correct_answer: D. Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ham test detects lysis of red blood cells in a mildly acidic pH, a hallmark of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) , due to the deficiency of protective proteins like CD55 and CD59 on the RBC surface.
  • ➤ Ham test
  • ➤ lysis of red blood cells
  • ➤ paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)
  • ➤ CD55 and CD59

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He has hyperpigmentation on the skin and a higher risk of developing skin cancer, as indicated by his physician. Which of the following is a likely enzyme defect in the patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Nucleotide excision repair gene defect
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair gene defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nucleotide excision repair gene defect is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms in Xeroderma Pigmentosum , characterized by DNA repair failure after UV exposure, leading to hyperpigmentation and an increased risk of skin cancer .
  • ➤ nucleotide excision repair gene defect
  • ➤ Xeroderma Pigmentosum
  • ➤ DNA repair failure
  • ➤ hyperpigmentation
  • ➤ skin cancer

questions.text: A 43-year-old man has complained of heartburn for the past 5 months. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed. Biopsies are taken from an erythematous area of the lower esophageal mucosa. There is no mass lesion and no hemorrhage. The biopsies have the microscopic appearance shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Epithelial metaplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The histological findings of intestinal metaplasia (columnar epithelium with goblet cells) in the lower esophagus are consistent with Barrett's esophagus , which is caused by chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is an example of epithelial metaplasia .
  • ➤ intestinal metaplasia
  • ➤ lower esophagus
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus
  • ➤ gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • ➤ epithelial metaplasia

questions.text: A clinical study is performed with subjects who developed a skin rash. Skin biopsies from these subjects are analyzed by immunofluorescence. Some of the subjects have the immunofluorescence pattern shown here, with antibody to IgG. This appearance is most likely to be based upon which of the following pathologic mechanisms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antigen-antibody complex deposition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The linear immunofluorescence pattern with IgG deposition is characteristic of immune complex deposition , seen in diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) , where antigen-antibody complexes are deposited along the basement membrane.
  • ➤ linear immunofluorescence pattern
  • ➤ IgG deposition
  • ➤ immune complex deposition
  • ➤ systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • ➤ antigen-antibody complexes

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has had abdominal pain for the past 3 days. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed, and the gastric mucosa has the appearance depicted in the image shown below. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely to be involved in this appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostaglandins are essential for maintaining gastric mucosal protection , and their reduction, often due to NSAID use , leads to gastric erosions and inflammation, as seen in this patient.
  • ➤ Prostaglandins
  • ➤ gastric mucosal protection
  • ➤ NSAID use
  • ➤ gastric erosions

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with a squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung. While performing a pneumonectomy, the thoracic surgeon notes that the hilar lymph nodes are small, 0.5 to 1.0 cm in size, and jet black in color throughout. The microscopic appearance of one lymph node is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this lymph node?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anthracosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The black pigmentation of the hilar lymph nodes in this patient, who likely has a smoking history, is consistent with anthracosis , which is the accumulation of carbon particles from inhaled pollutants or smoke.
  • ➤ black pigmentation
  • ➤ anthracosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has been a cigarette smoker since the age of 18, averaging a pack a day of unfiltered cigarettes. She works as a dispatcher for a trucking company. She has had several episodes of hemoptysis in the past two weeks along with fatigue, headache, nausea, and anorexia. On physical examination, her sensorium is clouded. A chest radiograph shows an ill-defined hilar mass. A transbronchial lung biopsy is performed, and the microscopic appearance is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyponatremia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is frequently associated with hyponatremia due to SIADH . The clinical presentation of this patient, including clouded sensorium and smoking history, is suggestive of this paraneoplastic syndrome.
  • ➤ Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • ➤ hyponatremia
  • ➤ SIADH
  • ➤ clouded sensorium

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with atherosclerotic heart disease has been experiencing increasing lethargy for the past 5 years. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show serum creatinine of 6 mg/dL and urea nitrogen of 64 mg/dL. The microscopic appearance of his kidneys is shown. Which of the following findings on urinalysis is most specific for the underlying disease leading to this appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Microalbuminuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of microalbuminuria is an early and specific marker of glomerular injury in hypertensive nephropathy , which progresses to more significant kidney damage, as evidenced by glomerulosclerosis in the kidney biopsy.
  • ➤ microalbuminuria
  • ➤ glomerular injury
  • ➤ hypertensive nephropathy
  • ➤ glomerulosclerosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about TRALI?

options.label: A
options.text: Seen most frequently with fresh frozen plasma

options.label: B
options.text: Pathogenesis is explained by double hit hypothesis

options.label: C
options.text: Anti HLA antibodies of recipient against donor antigens is causative in nature

options.label: D
options.text: Occurs usually within 6 hours of starting transfusion

questions.correct_answer: C. Anti HLA antibodies of recipient against donor antigens is causative in nature
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti HLA antibodies of recipient against donor antigens is causative in nature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In TRALI , the pathogenesis involves donor antibodies (anti-HLA or anti-neutrophil) reacting against the recipient’s leukocytes , leading to acute lung injury. The clinical presentation typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion, with a significant association with FFP transfusion.
  • ➤ TRALI
  • ➤ donor antibodies
  • ➤ recipient’s leukocytes
  • ➤ within 6 hours
  • ➤ FFP

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with easy bruising, bleeding gums, and fatigue. Laboratory results show pancytopenia, and peripheral blood smear reveals numerous abnormal promyelocytes with characteristic faggot cells. Flow cytometry is performed, confirming the presence of CD13, CD33, and CD117 on the surface of the abnormal cells. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) t (15;17) translocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is most commonly associated with the t(15;17) translocation, which creates the PML-RARα fusion gene and leads to the accumulation of abnormal promyelocytes with distinctive features, such as faggot cells .
  • ➤ Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML)
  • ➤ t(15;17)
  • ➤ PML-RARα fusion gene
  • ➤ faggot cells

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be observed in a patient diagnosed with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark features of PNH are hemolysis , thrombosis , and aplastic anemia , while the development of leukemia is uncommon and not a typical feature of this condition.
  • ➤ hallmark features
  • ➤ PNH
  • ➤ hemolysis
  • ➤ thrombosis
  • ➤ aplastic anemia
  • ➤ leukemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with proteinuria and hypertension. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of diabetic nephropathy?

options.label: A
options.text: Granular immune complex deposition along the glomerular capillary walls

options.label: B
options.text: Linear IgG and C3 deposition along the glomerular basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: D. Mesangial expansion with nodular glomerulosclerosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mesangial expansion with nodular glomerulosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark of diabetic nephropathy is mesangial expansion with nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions). The earliest lesion in diabetic nephropathy is glomerular basement membrane thickening , followed by mesangial matrix expansion and eventual nodular sclerosis.
  • ➤ diabetic nephropathy
  • ➤ mesangial expansion
  • ➤ nodular glomerulosclerosis
  • ➤ glomerular basement membrane thickening

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of IBD presents with elevated liver enzymes. On imaging, multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are noted. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and hypergammaglobulinemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates onion-skin fibrosis around small- and medium-sized bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic biliary disease commonly associated with IBD and characterized by multifocal strictures , onion-skin fibrosis , and an elevated risk of developing liver cirrhosis and cholangiocarcinoma . The presence of onion-skin fibrosis and biliary strictures in a patient with IBD strongly suggests PSC.
  • ➤ Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
  • ➤ IBD
  • ➤ multifocal strictures
  • ➤ onion-skin fibrosis
  • ➤ liver cirrhosis
  • ➤ cholangiocarcinoma
  • ➤ onion-skin fibrosis
  • ➤ biliary strictures

questions.text: A 17-year-old presented with intussusception and was found to have a polyp. A biopsy was taken and is shown. What is the likely correct statement about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Rectum is the MC site for this lesion

options.label: C
options.text: May be associated with meningioma and dermoid cyst

questions.correct_answer: D. AMP kinase may be affected
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AMP kinase may be affected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is characterized by hamartomatous polyps , predominantly in the jejunum , and mucocutaneous pigmentation . The syndrome is linked to mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene , affecting the AMP kinase pathway .
  • ➤ Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS)
  • ➤ hamartomatous polyps
  • ➤ jejunum
  • ➤ mucocutaneous pigmentation
  • ➤ mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene
  • ➤ AMP kinase pathway

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with chronic fatigue. Physical examination reveals slight jaundice and splenomegaly. The results of laboratory studies include hemoglobin of 11.8 g/dL and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. The osmotic fragility of the patient’s RBCs is increased, but the Coombs test is negative. Defect in which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythrocyte cytoskeleton

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hereditary spherocytosis involves a defect in the erythrocyte cytoskeleton , leading to the formation of spherocytes , which have increased osmotic fragility and cause hemolysis .
  • ➤ Hereditary spherocytosis
  • ➤ erythrocyte cytoskeleton
  • ➤ spherocytes
  • ➤ osmotic fragility
  • ➤ hemolysis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has had back pain for 6 months. He recently developed a cough productive of yellowish sputum. On physical examination, he has no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. His temperature is 37.8°C. A radiograph of the spine reveals several 1 to 2 cm lytic lesions of the vertebral bodies. His serum urea nitrogen is 28 mg/dL and creatinine is 3.0 mg/dL. A sputum culture grows Streptococcus pneumoniae. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and the marrow smear is shown in the image. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?

options.label: B
options.text: Tear drop cells in peripheral blood

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypergammaglobulinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is characterized by lytic bone lesions, renal dysfunction, and hypergammaglobulinemia due to the overproduction of monoclonal immunoglobulins by neoplastic plasma cells.

questions.text: A student was working on sarcomas in his Cerebellum Research Labs. Tissue was having strong nuclear staining for myogenin and MyoD1, and its molecular studies (including FISH) demonstrated PAX-FOXO1 fusion gene product. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PAX-FOXO1 fusion gene and strong nuclear staining for myogenin and MyoD1 are hallmark features of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma , distinguishing it from other sarcomas.
  • ➤ PAX-FOXO1 fusion gene
  • ➤ myogenin
  • ➤ MyoD1
  • ➤ alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a thyroid nodule. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals papillary structures with psammoma bodies and nuclear abnormalities, including nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions as shown in the image. Which of the following factors most strongly predisposed this patient to the development of this thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exposure to ionizing radiation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exposure to ionizing radiation is a major risk factor for developing papillary thyroid carcinoma , characterized by psammoma bodies and nuclear grooves on histopathology.
  • ➤ Exposure to ionizing radiation
  • ➤ papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ psammoma bodies
  • ➤ nuclear grooves

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents with a high fever, fatigue, and a new-onset systolic murmur. Blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus viridans . He expired unfortunately, and his autopsy revealed the vegetations as shown in the image. Which of the following findings is not caused by an immunological phenomenon in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Janeway lesions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Janeway lesions in infective endocarditis are caused by septic emboli and are considered a vascular phenomenon , not an immunological one.
  • ➤ Janeway lesions
  • ➤ septic emboli
  • ➤ vascular phenomenon

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 80 fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serum ferritin levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia , serum ferritin levels are the most appropriate next step to confirm iron deficiency anemia , as ferritin levels are the first indicator to drop in iron deficiency.
  • ➤ microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • ➤ serum ferritin levels
  • ➤ iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 150,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a suspected case of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) , the most sensitive and specific test to confirm the diagnosis is FISH or PCR for the BCR-ABL fusion gene , a hallmark of CML caused by the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) .
  • ➤ chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
  • ➤ FISH or PCR
  • ➤ BCR-ABL fusion gene
  • ➤ Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with headache. Radiological examination reveals a 2 cm mass attached to the dura. Which of the following will most likely be observed on histopathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Psammoma Bodies with Whirling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies and whirling patterns are key histological features of meningioma , a common brain tumor that often presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and is associated with a dural attachment on imaging.
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies
  • ➤ whirling patterns
  • ➤ meningioma

questions.text: A lady presents with a lump and has been diagnosed with breast cancer. Her biopsy report revealed the presence of tumor cells with signet ring appearance, mucin deposition, and Indian file pattern. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis in her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Invasive lobular cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of signet ring cells , mucin deposition , and an Indian file pattern on biopsy is characteristic of invasive lobular carcinoma , which is often bilateral and associated with the CDH1 gene mutation .
  • ➤ signet ring cells
  • ➤ mucin deposition
  • ➤ Indian file pattern
  • ➤ invasive lobular carcinoma
  • ➤ CDH1 gene mutation

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with patches of thick skin in the forearm, dysphagia on and off. She presented with oliguria and decreased renal function for 1 week. Renal biopsy was performed. Which of the following findings can be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fibrinoid necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of scleroderma renal crisis , where high blood pressure causes endothelial damage leading to necrosis in the blood vessels.
  • ➤ Fibrinoid necrosis
  • ➤ scleroderma renal crisis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with a four-day history of cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The cough is productive of yellowish sputum. On physical examination, decreased breath sounds are auscultated on the right lower lung field, and dullness to percussion is noted in the same area. Antibiotics were started by the physician and he stated improving. Which of the following cytokines will most likely be seen in the resolution phase of bacterial pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IL-10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that plays a key role in the resolution phase of bacterial pneumonia, helping to suppress inflammation and promote tissue repair.
  • ➤ IL-10
  • ➤ anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • ➤ resolution phase

questions.text: Autoimmunity in EBV infection is the result of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polyclonal B cell activation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infections, autoimmunity arises due to polyclonal B-cell activation , leading to the production of autoantibodies that can target the body’s own tissues.
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)
  • ➤ polyclonal B-cell activation

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with painless lymphadenopathy, night sweats, and weight loss. A lymph node biopsy is done following which a diagnosis of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma is made. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

options.label: D
options.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.correct_answer: D. Poor prognosis compared to classical HL
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) has a better prognosis compared to classical Hodgkin lymphoma, and it is CD20-positive , CD30-negative , and typically EBV-negative .
  • ➤ Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL)
  • ➤ better prognosis
  • ➤ CD20-positive
  • ➤ CD30-negative
  • ➤ EBV-negative

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, arthralgia particularly in the hands, and a recent history of impotence. He has a bronze tint to his skin. His liver function tests show elevated transaminases, and his ferritin level is significantly elevated. His family history is notable for a brother who required liver transplantation due to liver failure of unknown cause. Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Mutation in the HFE gene
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mutation in the HFE gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HFE gene mutation , particularly the C282Y variant , is the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis , leading to iron overload and affecting multiple organs such as the liver, skin, joints, and pancreas.
  • ➤ HFE gene mutation
  • ➤ C282Y variant
  • ➤ hereditary hemochromatosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes a liver biopsy for a lesion suspected to be focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) based on imaging studies. She has no significant medical history and normal liver function tests. Which special stain would be most useful in confirming the diagnosis of FNH in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reticulin stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH), reticulin stain is the most useful special stain, as it helps confirm the diagnosis by demonstrating the intact reticulin fiber network in the lesion.
  • ➤ reticulin stain

questions.text: A patient died of myocardial infarction, and his heart was taken out and immersed in a solution. The normal area of the heart turned brick red, whereas the infarcted part turned white. Which of the following is correct about the stain and the reactive enzyme?
questions.correct_answer: B. Triphenyl tetrazolum chloride and LDH1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Triphenyl tetrazolum chloride and LDH1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain is used to differentiate viable cardiac tissue from infarcted tissue in myocardial infarction. Viable tissue containing LDH1 turns brick red, while infarcted tissue remains white.
  • ➤ Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) stain
  • ➤ LDH1

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal bloating presents to the gastroenterology clinic. She reports that her symptoms seem to worsen after consuming bread and pasta. Physical examination is unremarkable, and celiac serology tests are positive. A biopsy of the small intestine is performed, which shows characteristic features of celiac disease. Which of the following morphological features would you NOT expect to find on the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria

questions.correct_answer: C. Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes . PAS-positive macrophages are a feature of Whipple's disease , not celiac disease.
  • ➤ Celiac disease
  • ➤ villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes
  • ➤ Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a progressive increase in dyspnea over the past five years presents for evaluation. He reports no significant past medical history but mentions that his younger brother has similar respiratory complaints. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds throughout all lung fields. A chest X-ray shows a flattened diaphragm and increased lucency in all lung fields, suggestive of hyperinflation. Pulmonary function tests reveal a decreased forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and an increased forced vital capacity (FVC). Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying his pulmonary pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Reduced anti-elastase activity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency causes reduced anti-elastase activity , leading to early-onset panacinar emphysema in younger patients, even those without a history of smoking.
  • ➤ Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • ➤ reduced anti-elastase activity
  • ➤ early-onset panacinar emphysema

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the oncology clinic with a history of painless lymphadenopathy. She reports noticing swollen lymph nodes in her neck and axilla over the past few months, which have gradually increased in size. She denies fever, night sweats, or weight loss. On physical examination, multiple non-tender, rubbery lymph nodes are palpated in the cervical and axillary regions. A biopsy of one of the lymph nodes is performed, revealing a lymphoma characterized by a distinctive pattern of small B-lymphocytes mixed with larger, transformed cells within follicle-like structures. Immunohistochemistry shows overexpression of a protein known to inhibit apoptosis, contributing to the pathogenesis of this lymphoma by prolonging cell survival. Which of the following lymphomas is most likely associated with the over-expression of this protein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follicular lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular lymphoma is associated with the overexpression of the BCL-2 protein , which inhibits apoptosis, allowing malignant B cells to survive. It often presents with painless lymphadenopathy and shows follicular-like structures on biopsy.
  • ➤ Follicular lymphoma
  • ➤ BCL-2 protein
  • ➤ painless lymphadenopathy
  • ➤ follicular-like structures

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with a reduced life span?

options.label: A
options.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduced activity of sirtuins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reduced activity of sirtuins is associated with a reduced lifespan due to their important role in promoting cellular longevity and stress resistance. Conversely, increasing sirtuin activity is linked to improved lifespan and healthspan.
  • ➤ Reduced activity of sirtuins
  • ➤ reduced lifespan
  • ➤ improved lifespan

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon where certain genes are expressed differently depending on whether they are inherited from the mother or the father. Disorders like Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes arise due to such parent-specific gene expression patterns.
  • ➤ Genomic imprinting
  • ➤ Prader-Willi
  • ➤ Angelman syndromes

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60 fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia and a low Mentzer index (below 13), HbA2 levels should be measured to investigate the possibility of thalassemia trait , particularly beta-thalassemia.
  • ➤ HbA2 levels
  • ➤ thalassemia trait
